As your listeners may be interested to know, Project Bioshield has three components.

One is a set of special new authorities for the National Institutes of Health that allow them to go more rapidly and take certain streamlined approaches in their research and development programs related to new countermeasures against terrorism agents.

Second, new authorities for the Food and Drug Administration, in particular, that allow what's called an emergency use authorization for products that are well-advanced in their development but not, perhaps, quite at the provable stage, but that could be used in an emergency situation.

And, third, and, in many ways, most important, the special reserve fund of $5.6 billion over a 10-year period, to allow for the acquisition of large quantities of countermeasures for addition to the Strategic National Stockpile, and then for distribution and use, under various emergency circumstances.
So what have you got in the stockpile at this point?

Well, the major developments from the Project Bioshield acquisitions has been the contracting for a new anthrax vaccine, one made with modern production techniques, and our goal here is to have 75 million doses of this vaccine.
This would--is--the first 25 million doses would be scheduled for some time in the year '06.
That would allow for coverage of the first 25 million doses.

We have in the interim also acquired the five million doses of the existing anthrax vaccine made with an older production technology but one that is approved for use and is used by the military in particular.

And that is already being added to the stockpile incrementally with our purchases, and then we've also made the purchase of a pediatric form of potassium iodine, a special formulation for children to protect against the radiation from radioactive iodine in the event of either a nuclear power plant event or some terrorism event that involved radioactive iodine.
So how--OK, so you got iodine and you've got--or you've got I guess bids out to get anthrax vaccine and you've got iodine.
